head.title: The Recruit. A Musical Interlude.1, 1First published in Poems (1794), pp. 37-48, and performed in Dumfries in January, 1794; subsequent performances in Charleston include March 12, 1796 and May 30, 1807. Turnbull regularly included the play in the program for his benefit nights. He and his wife played the leading roles as Sampson and Nell, the argumentative husband and his equally argumentative wife. Though the play’s opening draws its humour from marital conflict, threatened domestic violence, and gender stereotyping, the wife gives as good as she gets: when Sampson threatens to leave her and join the army, she initially tells him to go, as he’s worthless anyway. The denouement of the play, when Nell wants him back, might seem a triumph for Sampson, but to get his release from the army and return to Nell Sampson has to accept his daughter Olly’s wish to marry the Sergeant, which he had previously refused. Sampson fits the stereotype of the village shoemaker or cobbler, as a self-employed and independently-minded craftsman who (to the resentment of his wife) worked intermittently and took time off to go drinking with friends; he also fits the shoemaker stereotype in bring physically small, by contrast with the recruiting sergeant and his the drummer. (Since there is no surviving portrait of Turnbull, this is the only clue there is to his own physical appearance.) The language in the play, though sometimes typographically vernacular, is easy enough to follow when it is acted or read aloud. The annotations here focus less on glossing words than on background, allusions or situations that might be missed in reading. 22 One of the few ways for a man to make a clean break from Scottish rural or small-town life was to join the army, and for those with no other recourse enlistment became a traditional if drastic escape route from sexual, marital, financial and legal difficulties. Cf. Song IV. Unlike the navy, which sent press-gangs ashore to seize men to become seamen, the army relied on volunteers, sending a recruiting sergeant with a few soldiers (here just a drummer) to country towns and villages, who drink with likely recruits, whose acceptance of a small enlistment payment, “the King’s shilling,” usually spent in celebration with the sergeant, constituted an irrevocable commitment.

performance.p: As performed at the Theatre, Dumfries, January 1794.

lg.l: Nane o’ yer jaw, or by my saul I’ll do’t—
This vera day ye’ll see me a recruit.
Think ye I’ll leave forever in het water,
And be dung deaf wi’ your eternal clatter!
Sae close your slav’ring gab, ye senseless taupie,

Or damn me! by St Crispian!33 Patron saint of cobblers and shoemakers, the appropriate oath for depicting Sampson’s occupation, but also part of theatre lore from the Agincourt scene in Shakespeare’s Henry V. but I’ll strap ye.
Ye’ll strap me faith ! it sets you weel to speak,
After ye’ve tippl’d a’ this blessed week
Wi’ drunken Pate the smith, and Mungo Bell,
And other graceless wretches like yersel’—
Whilst I, a virtuous wife as e’er was seen,
Sit spinning by mysel’ frae morn ’till e’en;
And scrape and had thegether a’ I can,
To serve a silly good-fornaething man:
Gae list, and send ye quickly o’er the sea,
For day, or night, ye’re naething worth to me!

sp.speaker: SAMPSON.
sp.l: There the shoe pinches—44 In response to Nell’s accusation that Sampson is “naething worth” to her “for …night,” but perhaps less an admission of his own sexual inadequacy than a hint at her sexual demands. Either way, again a relevant proverbial phrase for a shoemaker.

lg.l: Hold your senseless tongue—
I might hae had a lad baith fair and young,
And rich, and good—but nae sic luck for me;
I wish I’d dy’d the day I married thee!
I’ll tell ye, Nell, be sparing o’ yer clatter—
Ye married me when ye cou’d do nae better!
Nae better troth! ye ugly, chreeshy55 adj. greasy. ghaist!
I’m sure I had an hundred lads amaist:
Ane o’ them dy’d for love o’ me, that’s fact;
The Farmer ran about me till he brake.66 Went bankrupt.
Tam Piper left the country,77 Travelling pipers were a byword for brief sexual encounters. and the Taylor
Ran aff to Leith and listed for a sailor.
And then the Laird——
My dear, mak out the sentence——

Made you ascend the black-stool o’ repentance.88 The cutty stool in church on which offenders stood for public rebuke, when detected as having had pre- or extra- marital sex, often because the woman was pregnant.
What! out o’ countenance?—Ay, now ye’re catch’d.
Well, than, there cou’d nae be twa be better match’d;
Ye ken fu’ weel, guidman, thousands can tell,
The like good-fortune99 Sampson as well as Nell had had to make public penance for pre-marital sex. happen’d to yoursel’!
Happen’d to me !—Ay, troth indeed that’s true:
I maun confess she’s equal wi’ me now.

titlePart.note: 10 First published as "Song III" in Poetical Essays, (1788), pp. 216-217; reprinted in Poems (1794), pp. 38-39; and again with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796). The air Turnbull used, “The Muckin’ o’ Geordie’s Byre,” had appeared in Orpheus Caledonius (1733), no. 33; Caledonian Pocket Companion, II (1745), p. 35; and (with earlier words) in Johnson, Scots Musical Museum, I (1787), no. 96; it was also used later by Burns for his song “Adown winding Nith I did wander” (Kinsley II:701), published in Thomson, Select Collection of Original Scotish Airs, II: set 3 (1799), song 66.

lg.l: Ye lads, that are plaugit wi’ lasses,
Had need to be tenty and slie;
Or soon ye’ll be guidit like asses,
If ye be as silly as me.
I courted a lassie for siller,
And she was right saucy and sprie;
But gin I was buckl’d until her
The fient a scrap siller had she.
But ken’t ye the way how I gat her,
Ye’d say it was cunning o’ me:
The chiels a’ gaed wood to be at her,
Sae cadgie the siller to see;
But I gied her something to carry,
A sure memorandum to be;
And syne she consented to marry,
And wad hae nae other but me.
In a doop she began to grow wally,
The neighbours a’ ferlit to see;
But I kent the reason fu’ brawly,
Wha soon was a daddy to be.
And when the black cutty we mountit,
Her lads a’ leugh hearty at me:
But, O! how my courage was bluntit,
When fient a scrap siller had she.
Hey ho! this love ! this love is such an evil—
’Tis worse than debt, or drink,—ay ’tis the devil!
I’ve trv’d to shake it off, but all in vain;
Spite of all arts I’ve got the fit again.

front.titlePart: Song II.1111 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 39-40; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.l: My friends, unfeelingly, condemn
My passion for my Polly;1212 Sampson and Nell’s daughter.
They mock my sighs, and bid me leave
This am’rous melancholy.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her!
The chearful glass, the jovial crew,
That were my pleasure wholly,
No more can ease this aching heart
That burns for thee, my Polly.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her!
Forbear, unfeeling men, to rail,
Nor call my passion folly;
I’d sooner die, than cease to love
My dear, my charming Polly.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her !
Aye, there my noble Serjeant sighing stands,
A love-sick swain—
Well, Jack, what’s your demands?
You know, you sent me to enquire about
Your girl, and I have found a secret out:
You’ve lost your chance—
Curse on my luckless fate!—
I wish to see her though, at any rate:
She lov’d me once—I’m sure I’d wed her still,
If I could but secure her father’s will.
His will!—that I’ll procure you in a trice,
Dear Serjeant, if you’ll follow my advice.
You know how many wenches I have trick’d,
How many country bumpkins I have nick’d—
I’ve seen your Polly, and she loves you yet;
Her, with her father’s free consent ye’ll get;
But follow my directions—
Never fear——
Who’s this?—By all my hopes, it is my dear!
What, my sweet creature! ever kind and true?
Yes, my dear Serjeant, ever so to you;
Why did you leave me tho’?—Ah! I’m afraid
You left your Polly for some other maid:
Your vows and promises are false as wind,
For you’re to all, as to your Polly kind.
Do stop that pretty lying tongue a while,
And cheer your faithful soldier with a smile.
How does all friends? does thy dad relent?
And may we ever hope for his consent?

sp.speaker: POLLY.1313 The 1794 text was here misprinted with the name "Molly."

lg.l: No, he relents not ; but what’s that to me!
My heart, my dearest soldier’s still with thee.
My mother rages, and my father swears,
They growl like greedy wolves and raging bears
He’ll see you shortly ; but howe’er it be,
Secure old dad, and then ye’re sure of me.
Lord ! what care I for he or she!
Why let them scold and hollo;
O’er hill and dale, by land and sea,
My soldier I will follow.
Then come, my dearest, to my arms,
I’ll add thee to my roll1414 I.e. enlist her, as metaphor for marrying. O!
And leave for thine all other charms,
If your dear lad you’ll follow.
Here comes the Cobbler.—Drummer, mind your duty.
Yes, Serjeant, for the cause is love and beauty.
Ay, there’s the lads that lead the merry lives,
Free frae hard labour and ill-natur’d wives:
While I, poor devil, darna tak a chapin,1515 n. (Scottish) half pint.
But my unruly spouse is on my tappin.1616 n. Crown of the head.
I’ll sell ye her, good Serjeant, if ye’ll tak her,
And try if only better ye can make her.
Old boy, I thought you had not need of telling,
There’s better ways to tame a wife than selling.1717 Selling off a difficult wife was a traditional trope in country folk-lore: cf. Hardy’s The Mayor of Casterbridge.
How, how, dear sir?—come tell me that wi’ speed;
Ne’er ane to learn that lesson had mair need.
Listen, old boy; and if you be a man,
I’ll try to raise your courage, if I can.

front.titlePart: Song IV.1818 First published in Poems (1794), p. 42; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.l: The youth who is handsome, courageous, and wise,
Will poverty, hardship, and labour despise;
The spade and the cart, the flail and the plough,
He’ll leave when he hears our row-de-dow-dow!1919 Accompanied by a rousing drum-roll to stimulate recruiting.
The lad who’s in love, and his sweatheart unkind,
Let him cast all his cares at his back to the wind;
Nor to a coy mistress contentedly bow,
But leave her at once for our row-de-dow-dow!
The man who is tied up in wedlock’s close noose,
May quickly get rid of a termagant spouse;
Let her bellow and scold, the best he can do
Is, to leave her at once for our row-de-dow-dow!
There, my old boy !
Ay, faith! that sang has merit——.
Then leave your wife, if you’re a man of spirit.
I had a wife, in sooth a very devil!
But since I listed she’s been vastly civil,
And let’s me live as happy as a prince;—
For faith, old boy, I’ve never seen her since!
What mean you, Jack? the man’s not worth a shilling!2020 On agreeing to enlist, a recruit was given “the King’s shilling.”
Ne’er mind, but list the body, if he is willing:
Mind what your Polly said, play well your part,
You’ll get the daughter for the father’s smart.
Here, brother Crispian,2121 The cobbler, Sampson. will you take a crown?2222 Five shillings. The crown was a silver coin, but is here described as gold.
I thank ye, sir ; I’ve siller of my own.—
I’ll tell though, as ye’re a man of honour;
My wife, I mean to put a trick upon her;
For as she scalds me wheresoe’er I gang,
At hame, abroad, alane, or in a thrang;
As she’s sae thrawart, this I’ve done to grieve her,
Sworn that this vera day I’ll list and leave her.

Bravely determined !—here’s the yellow gold.2323 Sampson has refused both a shilling and a crown (five shillings), both silver coins. The Serjeant now offers him gold as an enlistment payment, either a half-guinea (10 s. 6 d.) or a guinea (21 shillings), and Sampson accepts.
I take it—that will learn the jade to scold!
And now, as I hae frankly tald ye a’
My hale intention, sir, without a flaw,
Should Nell relent, and she and I agree,
Ye’ll take your goud again and let me free.
Where is the monster? where’s the drunken brute?
’Tis as I tauld ye, Nell, I’m a recruit;
See there’s the yellow lad——
’Nane o’ yer blether,
Ye auld mis-shapen lump o’ rotten leather:
Listed indeed !—goodman—no just sae fast—
“Let nae the soutter2424 n. shoemaker. go beyond his last.”2525 n. the metal foot-mould used both by shoe-makers; so proverbial for keeping to one’s own business.
I see, good-wife, ye think I’m but in jest;
But sure as we were kippl’d by the Priest,
I’m fairly listed—and before to-morrow
Gaes o’er yer head, ye’ll find it to yer sorrow.
Come, comrades, let us march—
My ain dear jewel,
How can you, O how can you be sae cruel
To leave yer wife and daughter here to starve!
Indeed, good-wife, it’s whats ye weel deserve;
For, day or night yer tongue lies never still,
But yelps just like the clapper o’ a mill.
If, in the morning, wi’ our neibour Tam
I gang to Mungo Blue’s2626 The inn or ale-house. to get a dram;
Scarce can I touch the glass or lift the jug,
Till your damn’d voice gaes yelling thro’ my lug:—
But should I leave the sodgers and gay hame,
Will this last bout yer thrawart temper tame?
May, that it will—and I shall a’ my life
Remain thy loving and obedient wife.
Weel, say nae mair, dear Nell, but kiss and gree!
And now, good sergeant, you and I are free.
No faith! old split-birss,2727 n. gad-fly you must go with me:
Long have I wish’d to catch you on the hip;
And now I’ll see you damn’d before ye slip.
Good lord! what madness !—ay, it’s just the case—
I’ve bit my nose aff just to vex my face!
I wisely laid this plot to humble Nell,
But run my head into the girn mysel’!
I hae five shillings, tied up in a clout,
And four-pence half-penny, or thereabout,
I hae a siller broach, just like a heart,
I gat frae Andrew Hogg that drave the cart,
I hae a ring—’tis either goud or brass—
A thimble, hussy,2828 n. a "house-wife" or sewing bag. and a keeking-glass,2929n. looking-glass, mirror.
And three scotch boddles,3030 n. a copper coin known also as Turners or Twopenny pieces, equivalent to one sixth of an English penny. I hae keepet lang,
Ye’s get them a’ if ye’ll but let him gang.
Dear serjeant, tak her crown, and tak her ring,
Tak a’ she has, before I serve the king;
Tak a’ that’s hers, dear sir, and then tak mine;
First, tak my auld black coat that’s superfine,
And tak my waistcoat and my three-square hat,
That at the last St Crispain’s day I gat;
Take breeks and apron, a’ that I can spare;
Tak strap, last, awl ;—and ye can take nae mair.
Can this be true, this woeful news I hear—
My father listed?—gentlemen, forbear;
Forgive a poor old man, who in a passion
Has done a thing against his inclination.
Yes, my dear maid, if any thing could plead,
Your tears should set your father free indeed;
But I have made an oath, and that I’ll keep,
To swear him and attest him e’re I sleep.
Take him along——
Nay, now, kind gentlemen,—I pray be civil—
Upon my saul, I never meant you evil!
Old boy, you say you never meant us ill—
Do you mean well to those that you would kill?
A twelve-month past—remember this, old dad,
The Serjeant, here, your daughter would have wed;
But you got drunk and made so damnd a fuss,
And with a rusty sword and blunderbuss,
Swore wounds and death ! that if he married Polly,
You’d make him in his blood repent his folly!
Yes, I remember’t, and to shew you now
That, that fools trick as weel as this I rue;
Tak back yer goud, and without farther strife,
Tak ye my daughter.—and I’ll tak my wife.
To shew you, sir, that I’m a man of feeling,3131 The vaguest of references to the cult of genteel sensibility, represented by Henry Mackenzie’s novel The Man of Feeling (1771).
I’ll take the ransome—fair one, if you’re willing:
Prouder of this recruit—I tell you true,
Than of a regiment such old fools as you.
To save my father, witness all that’s here,
I give my hand, a hearty volunteer.
By our example let ilk married pair
Of quarrels and domestic strife beware;
And, should a brawl ensue, ne’er gae about
Like us twa fools to let the secret out:
But when ye’re tir’d o’ flyting,3232 Public disputation involving personal attack. trust ye me,
The best thing ye can do, ’s to kiss and gree!

titlePart.note: 33 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 46-47; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.l: Now, Nell, since we’re ance mair agreed,
I’ll to my mending soals wi’ speed;
Mind you yer wheel—and as for you,
You’ve got the lad with the row, dow, dow !
Old boy, be wise and mind your trade,
And, Nell, let that curs’d tongue be laid,
Lest ye provoke him, when he’s fou’,
To follow the lads with the row, dow, dow!
Then farewel, mam, and farewel dad!
I’ll march along with my soldier lad;
Love gives the word, and our hearts beat true
With mutual joy, a row, dow, dow!
In peace, or war, whate’er betide,
With such a sweet and charming bride
I’m bless’d for life—and chear’d by you,
I’ll boldly march to the row, dow, dow !
